{{Use Australian English|date=November 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2013}} {{Infobox military person | name = Langford Wellman Colley-Priest | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = September 1890 | death_date = February 1928 (aged 37) | birth_place = [[Glebe, New South Wales]] | death_place = [[Balmoral, New South Wales]] | allegiance = Australia | branch = [[First Australian Imperial Force|Australian Imperial Force]] | serviceyears = 1915–1919 | rank = Private | servicenumber = 6618 | unit = [[8th Field Ambulance (Australia)|8th Australian Field Ambulance]] | commands = | battles = First World War * [[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]]: ** [[Battle of the Somme]] ** Battle of Racquinghem **[[Battle of Polygon Wood]] ** [[Battle of Messines (1917)|Battle of Messines]] ** [[Second Battle of Villers-Bretonneux]] ** [[Battle of Mont Saint-Quentin]] | awards = [[Military Medal]] }} '''Langford Wellman Colley-Priest''' [[Military Medal|MM]] (September 1890 – 11/12 February 1928)[http://recordsearch.naa.gov.au/scripts/Imagine.asp?B=3270889&I=1&SE=1 Enlistment paper]. ''National Archive of Australia'': p. 1. Retrieved 23 November 2013. was an Australian [[stretcher bearer]] during the [[First World War]] for the [[8th Field Ambulance (Australia)|8th Field Ambulance]]. He was awarded the [[Military Medal]] for conspicuous gallantry on the [[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]] in 1917. He survived the war but later drowned in 1928, and his body is believed to have been eaten by a [[shark]]. ==Early life== Colley-Priest was born in [[Glebe, New South Wales]], in September 1890 to George and Rose Colley-Priest.{{cite web|title=NSW BDM index search|publisher=NSW Registry of Births, Deaths and Marriages|url=http://www.bdm.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/IndexSearch?form=IndexingSearch&cgiurl=%2Fcgi-bin%2FIndex%2FIndexingBirth.cgi&sname=Colley&gname=&fname=&mname=&event=deaths&frange=1928&trange=1928&place=Sydney&x=43&y=12&SessionID=42768051|accessdate=23 November 2013}} Prior to his embarkation for Egypt and deployment on the [[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]] he resided with his parents in [[Neutral Bay, New South Wales|Neutral Bay]] and worked as a warehouseman. Colley-Priest was an Anglican. ==Service== Colley-Priest enlisted in the [[8th Field Ambulance (Australia)|8th Field Ambulance]], part of the [[8th Brigade (Australia)|8th Infantry Brigade]] of the [[First Australian Imperial Force|Australian Imperial Force]], on 19 May 1915 and embarked aboard the [[HMAT Ascanius]] on 9 November, bound for Egypt and the Western Front.[http://recordsearch.naa.gov.au/scripts/Imagine.asp?B=3270889&I=1&SE=1 Enlistment paper]. ''National Archive of Australia'': p. 14. Retrieved 23 November 2013.{{cite web|title=Langford Wellman Colley-Priest|url=http://www.awm.gov.au/people/rolls/R1901382/|work=First World War Embarkation Rolls|publisher=Australian War Memorial|accessdate=23 November 2013}} While serving, he was deployed at [[Battle of the Somme|the Somme]], Racquinghem, [[Battle of Polygon Wood|Polygon Wood]], [[Battle of Messines (1917)|Messines]], [[Second Battle of Villers-Bretonneux|Villers-Bretonneux]] and [[Battle of Mont Saint-Quentin|Mont Saint-Quentin]]. In 1917, Colley-Priest was awarded the [[Military Medal]].{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article15777831 |title=Australians Honoured |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=28 December 1917 |accessdate=23 November 2013 |page=7 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} The recommendation for the award noted that he displayed: {{cquote|... conspicuous gallantry devotion to duty whilst continuously carrying wounded from that post to [[Second Battle of Ypres#Battle of Bellewaarde (24–25 May)|Belawaarde Ridge]] under very heavy shellfire of all kinds, [[explosive material|H.E.]], shrapnel and gas shells. On several occasions these men volunteered to carry urgent cases during a very intense period of heavy barrage. Throughout the action they showed great courage and devotion to duty, working continuously, and were responsible for saving many lives.|author=First World War Honours and Awards (Gazetted)|source={{cite web|url=http://www.awm.gov.au/research/people/honours_and_awards/person/R1593939/?roll_type=Recommendations |title=Honours and Awards — Langford William Colley-Priest|publisher=Australian War Memorial|date= |accessdate=23 November 2013}}}} [[File:Colley-Priest enlistment paper.jpeg|thumb|right|Colley-Priest's enlistment paper]] Colley-Priest returned to Australian in 1919, was discharged on 3 August and awarded the [[1914–15 Star]], [[British War Medal]] and [[Victory Medal (United Kingdom)|Victory Medal]]. for his war service.[http://recordsearch.naa.gov.au/scripts/Imagine.asp?B=3270889&I=1&SE=1 Enlistment paper]. ''National Archive of Australia'': p. 37. Retrieved 23 November 2013. He later wrote the official history of his unit.Colley-Priest, L. W., [http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/26863841?q&versionId=32370008 The 8th Australian Field Ambulance on active service : a brief account of its history and services from 4 August 1915 to 5 March 1919] (Sydney: D.S. Ford, 1919). Retrieved 23 November 2013. Notable for its first-hand accounts of the front from the perspective of medical staff, he sold his war diary to the [[State Library of New South Wales]] in 1919 as part of their ''European War Collecting Project''. {{cquote|''July 19th to July 22.''
10 p.m. News just came through that the Australians have taken two lines of trenches & captured a number of prisoners. A small batch of German prisoners just been marched by. About a dozen were brought in to our dressing station to have their wounds dressed. Their clothes I noticed were in good conditions. Number of Australian wounded keep coming in.
2 a.m. Orders to move off to the trenches to do our bit, all very anxious to be in the "Straffe" (If we only knew) The Sergeant in charge of the party took the wrong road, & we did not arrive at the other dressing station till about 3:30 a.m. Was very tired, no sleep. The sky looked beautiful, one mass of light & star-shells etc. & the booming of guns etc. was deafening. We had to start stretcher bearing immediately. I was working all that day, 36 hours altogether. The sight at the Dressing Station was terrible, hundreds of wounded men were lying about, some of them not recognisable, they were so shattered & covered in blood. The bearers carried these men after being looked at by the doctor, to the Motor Ambulances, about ¾ mile away. The noise of the guns grenades & machine guns was terrific. No one can realise what the noise is like unless they are close by.''|author=Langford Wellman Colley-Priest|source=[http://acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/_transcript/2012/D14133/a4954.htm Diary Transcription]. State Library of New South Wales. Retrieved 23 November 2013.}} ==Death== Colley-Priest went swimming on either 11 or 12 February 1928, at [[Balmoral, New South Wales|Balmoral Beach]], Sydney and was reported as missing on 13 February. On 14 February, a search team comprising the Balmoral local police and the New South Wales Water police were unable to find any signs of Colley-Priest. After the police search, a man observed a floating body in the distance and alerted the police to its presence. However, as the police approached the body a "huge object heaved out of the sea, grabbed the body, and disappeared." Newspapers at the time suggested suicide and that the body had been eaten by a shark.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article121862987 |title=Eaten by Shark? |newspaper=[[The Evening News (Sydney)|The Evening News]] |location=Sydney |date=16 February 1928 |accessdate=23 November 2013 |page=13 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16441970 |title=Missing Man |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |location=NSW |date=15 February 1928 |accessdate=23 November 2013 |page=19 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} On 27 February, an arm washed up on the beach near [[Dobroyd Point]] and was assumed to be Colley-Priest's. A suitcase with his clothes and a note stating "Colley-Priest gone mad" were found on Balmoral Wharf. Members of the Mosman and water police retrieved a portion of a shirt believed to have been worn by Colley-Priest.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article93663593 |title=Grim Relic on Beach |newspaper=[[The Northern Star]] |location=Lismore, NSW |date=27 February 1928 |accessdate=23 November 2013 |page=5 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [[State Library of New South Wales]] – [http://acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=862187 catalogue record] * [http://acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/_transcript/2012/D14133/a4954.htm Transcription of war diary] * [[Australian War Memorial]] – [http://www.awm.gov.au/collection/MSS1400/ record] * [http://www.awm.gov.au/research/people/honours_and_awards/person/R1546139/?roll_type=Awards AWM Award] * [http://www.worldcat.org/title/return-to-gallipoli-walking-the-battlefields-of-the-great-war/oclc/224801865 Return to Gallipoli: walking the battlefields of the Great War] * [http://mosman1914-1918.net/memorials/7/names/results.html/ Mosman-Neutral Bay Rifle Club Roll of Honour] {{DEFAULTSORT:Colley-Priest, Langford Wellman}} [[Category:1890 births]] [[Category:1928 deaths]] [[Category:Australian Anglicans]] [[Category:Australian military personnel of World War I]] [[Category:Australian soldiers]] [[Category:People declared dead in absentia]] [[Category:People who died at sea]] [[Category:Australian recipients of the Military Medal]]

'''Leader-1''' is the name of several [[fictional characters]] from the [[Go-Bots]], [[Robo Machine]]s and [[Transformers (toyline)|Transformers]] toy lines in 1983. The original Leader-1 was voiced by Lou Richards in the animated ''Challenge of the Gobots'' series. Since then Hasbro acquired legal rights to the name and has used it for a [[Mini-Con]].
==Gobots== {{Infobox character | name = Leader-1 | series = [[Challenge of the Gobots]]'', ''[[Machine Robo]]'', ''[[Robo Machine]]s'' and ''[[Transformers]] | image = | caption = | first = "The Battle for Gobotron" | creator = | portrayer = | voice = [[Lou Richards (actor)|Lou Richards]] | nickname = | alias = | species = Gobot | gender = Male | occupation = | title = | family = | spouse = | significantother = | children = | relatives = | religion = | nationality = | lbl1 = Japanese name |data1 = Eagle Robo | lbl2 = Release number |data2 = MR-25, BMR-02 | lbl21 = Abilities |data21 = Energy blasts, [[flight]], force field generation, [[shapeshifting]], superhuman durability, [[superhuman strength]] | lbl22 = Affiliation |data22 = Guardian Gobot | lbl23 = Alternate mode |data23 = [[F-15 Eagle]] }} In the animated series [[Challenge of the GoBots]], '''Leader-1''' is the leader of the Guardians.<ref>{{cite web|author=J.D. Reed |url=http://www.time.com/time/printout/0,8816,954424,00.html |title=Living: Hot Toys with a Special Twist - Printout |publisher=TIME |date=1984-10-01 |accessdate=2016-11-23}}</ref> He is a brave leader who cares deeply about his people. He believes not one person should be in charge. He supports the democratic system of the Guardians. This led his former friend, [[Cy-Kill]], to break away from the Guardians. He took command of the evil Renegades and became Leader-1's worst enemy.<ref>Vibe July 2007, page 40 "Do the Robot"</ref><ref>{{Cite book | title=Totally Tubular '80s | last=Bellomo | first=Mark | year=2010 | publisher=Krause Publications| ISBN=1-4402-1282-1 | pages= 90–93}}</ref>
Leader-1 can fly, project energy blasts, and project a force field (which rapidly drains his power reserves). He has been known to use Guardian power suits that increases his speed and strength.<ref>{{cite journal| journal =Toyfare |title=Going, Going, Gobots | author=Matt Caracappa | date=November 2007 |pages=80–82 |volume = 1 | issue = 123}}</ref>
===Animated series=== Leader-1 appeared in ''Challenge of the GoBots'' episode #8, "Time Wars."<ref>{{Cite episode |title= Time Wars |episodelink= |series= Challenge of the GoBots|serieslink= Challenge of the GoBots|credits= Written by Jeff Seagle, Kelly Ward and Doug Booth |network= First-run syndication|station= |airdate= September 17, 1985|season= 1|number= 8}}</ref>
In episode #14 "Ultra Zod" Leader-1 dons a Power Suit and helps form the Power Warrior Courageous, which defeats Ultra Zod.<ref>{{Cite episode |title= Ultra Zod|episodelink= |series= Challenge of the GoBots|serieslink= Challenge of the GoBots|credits= Written by Jim Bertges|network= First-run syndication|station= |airdate= September 25, 1985|season= 1|number= 14}}</ref>
In episode #23 "[[Doppelganger]]" [[Cy-Kill]], [[Cop-Tur]], [[Crasher (Gobots)|Crasher]] and Snoop attacked Leader-1, Turbo, Scooter and [[Small Foot (Gobots)|Small Foot]]. Crasher wounded Small Foot. After attaining recordings of the Guardians, the Renegades retreated. Using the recordings Cy-Kill had [[Herr Fiend]] program robot duplicates of the Guardians. When demonstrating the Space Bender weapon to Unicom, Leader-1 learned that the Renegades were attacking Washington. The Renegades ambushed Leader-1 and replaced him with his duplicate. Leading the Command Center back to GoBotron, and getting rid of Scooter and Small Foot, the Renegades then released duplicates of Path Finder, Rest-Q, [[Van Guard]] and Turbo. Small Foot and Scooter were able to capture the Turbo duplicate and learn where their friends were being held. Cy-Kill then replaced Good Night. Using the duplicate Turbo, the Guardians infiltrated the Renegade base, freed the captured Guardians and escaped from Spoons and [[Fitor]]. Although blocked by the Renegades, Scooter used a hologram of [[Zod (GoBots)|Zod]] to make the Renegades flee. Making it back to GoBotron the Guardians were attacked by the Guardian duplicates. The real Guardians were able to defeat their duplicates with the aid of the real [[Zeemon]], [[Hans-Cuff]] and Rest-Q. Cy-Kill then arrived in [[Thrustor]] with more duplicates, but Small Foot was able to stop with robots using the Space Bender, which would fuse their robot brains.<ref>{{Cite episode |title= Doppelganger|episodelink= |series= Challenge of the GoBots|serieslink= Challenge of the GoBots|credits= Written by Jeff Segal, Kelly Ward and Antoni Zalewski|network= First-run syndication|station= |airdate= October 11, 1985|season= 1|number= 23}}</ref>
In the episode #24 "Scooter Enhanced" Scooter and Small Foot joined Nick and A.J. to watch a car stunt show which was attacked by Crasher, [[BuggyMan]] and Fly Trap. Small Foot fought Buggyman and defeated him, but the Renegades regained the upper hand until the Guardians were rescued by Leader-1 and Turbo who arrived in Power Suits. Cy-Kill vowed to gain Power Suits for the Renegades. Scooter decided he needed more firepower, so he had [[Baron Von Joy]] remove his damaged holo projector in favor of a blaster unit. [[Screw Head]], Bad Boy and Cop-Tur were sent to attack Unicom bases and distract the Guardians while Cy-Kill, Crasher and Scorp attempted to take the suits from the Guardian Command Center. Small Foot and Scooter were able to delay the Renegades until Leader-1 and Turbo returned to chase away the Renegades. Realizing he was a better Guardian with his holo projector, Scooter had it reinstalled.<ref>{{Cite episode |title= Scooter Enhanced|episodelink= |series= Challenge of the GoBots|serieslink= Challenge of the GoBots|credits= Written by Jeff Segal, Kelly Ward and Mark Young |network= First-run syndication|station= |airdate= November 24, 1985|season= 1|number= 24}}</ref>
In episode #25, "Tarnished Image" Doctor Go creates a device that allows the Renegades to appear like Guardians. Cy-Kill, Crasher and Cop-Tur disguise themselves as Leader-1, Scooter and Turbo and go on a rampage on Earth while the real Guardians are sent on a fake rescue mission. When the Guardians return they are banished from Earth by the humans. The Guardians are eventually able to prove the Renegades staged the attacks, chase them off and capture Doctor Go.<ref>{{Cite episode |title= Tarnished Image|episodelink= |series= Challenge of the GoBots|serieslink= Challenge of the GoBots|credits=Written by Jeff Segal, Kelly Ward and David Schwartz |network= First-run syndication|station= |airdate=November 25, 1985 |season= 1|number= 25}}</ref>
Leader-1 appears in "Auto-Madic" episode #28, where he dons a Power Suit and helped form the Power Warrior Courageous, which defeats Puzzler.<ref>{{Cite episode |title= Auto-Madic |episodelink= |series= Challenge of the GoBots|serieslink= Challenge of the GoBots|credits= Written by Mark Zaslove |network= First-run syndication|station= |airdate= November 23, 1985|season= 1|number= 28}}</ref>
Leader-1 appeared in "Return to GoBotron" episode #45. He was given one of the Power Suits by the Last Engineer, which featured enhanced speed and strength. He combined with the other suits and the Last Engineer's ship to form the Power Warrior Courageous and defeat a fleet of Renegade Thrustors.<ref>{{Cite episode |title= Return to GoBotron |episodelink= |series= Challenge of the GoBots|serieslink= Challenge of the GoBots|credits= Written by Jeff Segal, Kelly Ward, John Loy and Peter Anderegg |network= First-run syndication|station= |airdate= November 15, 1985|season= 1|number= 45}}</ref>
Leader-1 appeared in episode #46, "Destroy All Guardians", where he helped form the Power Warrior Courageous to stop a group of cloned and mutated prehistoric reptiles from attacking Japan.<ref>{{Cite episode |title= Destroy All Guardians|episodelink= |series= Challenge of the GoBots|serieslink= Challenge of the GoBots|credits= Written by Don Glut |network= First-run syndication|station= |airdate= November 19, 1985|season= 1|number= 46}}</ref>
===Films=== Leader-1 lead the Guardian Gobot forces who aided the [[Rock Lord]] Boulder on the planet Cordax.<ref>{{cite video |people=[[Ray Patterson (animator)|Ray Patterson]] (Director), Kay Wright (Producer), Jeff Segal (Writer) |date=1986-03-21 |title=GoBots: Battle of the Rock Lords |medium=Motion picture |publisher=[[Clubhouse Pictures]]}}</ref>
===Comics=== Leader-1 appeared in the story "Scooter's Mighty Magnet."<ref>{{cite comic|title="Scooter's Mighty Magnet" |writer=Jay Itzkowitz|artist=[[Paul Kirchner]] |publisher=Telepictures Publications |date=Spring 1986}}</ref>
===Fun Publications=== Leader-1 appears among the group investigating the cataclysm destroying their universe in [[Fun Publications]] story ''[[Withered Hope]]''.<ref>{{cite book|title=Withered Hope|author=S. Trent Troop & Greg Sepelak|year=2008|publisher=The Transformers Collector’s Club}}</ref>
===Games=== Leader-1 was the playable character and clones of were among the cast in the video game ''Challenge of the Gobots'' for the Sinclair, Amstrad and Commodore 64.<ref>{{cite journal| title = Screen Shots: Challenge of the Gobots | journal = Your Sinclair| volume = 1 | issue = 20 | page = 70 | date = |url=http://www.worldofspectrum.org/showmag.cgi?mag=YourSinclair/Issue21/Pages/YourSinclair2100070.jpg}}</ref>
===Eagle=== Leader-1 appeared in the Eagle Comics story ''The Robo Machines''. He is a member of the Security Force Robo Machines.
===Other appearances=== Leader-1 was parodied in the [[CollegeHumor]] animated sketch "Transformers Go Hollywood". In the sketch, [[Optimus Prime]] and [[Megatron (Transformers)|Megatron]] talk about their [[Transformers (film)|live-action film]]'s success at a cafe when they are met by Leader-1, who works as a waiter in the cafe. Leader-1 is heavily ridiculed by Prime and Megatron as he attempts to give them the script to his proposed film project. He rushes to the restroom and talks to [[Johnny 5]] before locking himself in a toilet stall to cry over his insults.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20080330211051/http://www.collegehumor.com/video%3A1808795 ]</ref>
Leader-1 has appeared in the animated comedy series ''[[Robot Chicken]]''.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20070310084818/http://www.livevideo.com/video/1B1EFE9ACEEA464FB7DC19BB3DD440E7/gobot-nerd.aspx] </ref>
===Toys=== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:GobotToys.jpg|right|thumb|Leader-1 and other Gobot toys]] --> *'''''Gobots'' Leader-1''' (1983) :The toy of Leader-1 was originally [[Bandai]]'s ''Eagle Robo'' from their [[Machine Robo]] toyline.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aGb7o0TCiIE&feature=related|title=Vintage Go-Bots Commercial|first=|last=Scott R Heath|date=5 May 2007|website=Youtube.com|accessdate=23 November 2016|via=YouTube}}</ref> The gray Leader-1 was also sold as part of a limited edition gobots 3-pack <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.toyarchive.com/Gobots/3Packs/3Packs.html|title=STA: GoBots: Regular North America: GoBots: GoBots 3-Packs Boxed|website=Toyarchive.com|accessdate=23 November 2016}}</ref> with the other two figures being Flip-Top and [[Turbo]].
*'''''Gobots'' Super Leader-1''' (1984) :A larger "Super GoBot" <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.toyarchive.com/Gobots/SuperGobots/SuperGobots.html|title=STA: Gobots: Super Gobots|website=Toyarchive.com|accessdate=23 November 2016}}</ref> Leader-1 <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.toyarchive.com/Gobots/SuperGobots/Leader1.html|title=STA: Gobots: Super Gobots: Series 2: Guardian "Leader-1"|website=Toyarchive.com|accessdate=23 November 2016}}</ref> was later released.
*'''''Gobots'' Leader-1 redeco''' (1985) :The Tonka version was originally released in gray like Bandai's, but later versions were changed to a blue and white color scheme.
*'''''Gobots'' Model Leader-1''' :[[Monogram Models]] released Gobots model kits <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.toyarchive.com/Gobots/Models.html|title=STA: Go-Bots: Model Kits:Monogram Convertible Model Kits|website=Toyarchive.com|accessdate=23 November 2016}}</ref> which actually converted, and contained a Leader-1 model among 7 others. This toy was a redeco of a Legioss jet from the [[Genesis Climber MOSPEADA]] anime.
==Transformers: Armada== {{Transformers character| name =Leader-1 |image = |caption = |japanname =Barrel |affiliation =Mini-Con |subgroup = |rank = |function = |partner =Megatron |motto ="''Sometimes the least likely can be the most dangerous.''" or "''You're going down!''" |alternatemodes =Mobile Cannon |series =''[[Transformers: Armada]]'' |engvoice = |japanvoice = }} When Hasbro bought out Tonka, they assumed ownership of the GoBots character names. [[Megatron (Transformers)|Megatron]]'s Mini-Con in [[Transformers: Armada]] was named Leader-1 (Barrel in Japan). This character has no connection to the GoBot Leader-1. Leader-1 was later recolored into [[Clench (Transformers)|Clench]] (Spark Barrel) as a partner to Armada [[Galvatron]], then into [[Caliburn]] as a partner to [[Megazarak]].<ref>{{Cite book | title=Transformers: The Ultimate Guide | last=Furman | first=Simon | year=2004 | publisher=DK Publishing Inc.| ISBN=1-4053-0461-8 | page= 122}} </ref>
Leader-1 has two different official mottos. The first comes from his biography page in Dreamwave comics, and the second from his biography page in the ''Transformers: Armada Official Guidebook''.
Bio: [From the Troop Assessment Files of Megatron, Decepticon Leader] It's quite laughable, really. In the very core of his spark, Leader-1 truly believes that-somehow, some way-he'll eventually become a leader in fact and not just name. At first, he tried to ingratiate himself with me, doing everything from suggesting battle tactics on the field to helping keep the other Mini-Cons in line in order to win my favor. When it became clear that this behavior wouldn't convince me to let him assume a station of command, he resorted to open acts of treachery against me...I still haven't forgotten his homicidal insubordination on the Moon. Yet, his tenacity and ingenuity occasionally impress me; in these respects, he is far superior to the average Mini-Con. But that changes nothing. I will never allow a lowly Mini-Con to exert any control over my operations or me; they are tools to be manipulated, nothing more. For Leader-1 to believe he can be something more than that, to think for one astrosecond that he could ever stand with me as an equal, is ridiculous and insulting beyond words. I will dash his dreams at every turn until he understands his place...if he doesn't, then he will be discarded and replaced.
Weapons and Abilities: Although I'll never tell the little scraplet this, his abilities have proven valuable to me. Leader-1 is a surprisingly intelligent and tactically inclined Mini-Con; had he the fortune to be created a Decepticon instead of a Mini-Con, he would've made an excellent warrior. In addition to his mobile cannon mode, he can also transform into a powerful handgun for my use.
Weaknesses: Leader-1 gives himself more credit than he deserves. Although he's clever, his plans are too grandiose to be achieved by just him. After all, he's only a Mini-Con.
===Fun Publications=== In "Balancing Act" Leader-1 appeared among the rebel Mini-Con forces who sided with Megatron and attempted to sabotage the Mini-Con evacuation from one of Cybertron's moons.
===Dreamwave Productions=== [[File:ArmadaIssue6Leader1.jpg|left|thumb|Leader-1 in Dreamwave comics]] Leader-1 appeared among the Mini-Cons in issue #18 of the ''Transformers: Armada'' comic book who aided [[Over-Run]] using the [[Mini-Con Matrix]] in the defeat of Unicron.
===Toys=== *'''''Armada'' Megatron with Leader-1'' :This toy was redecoed into Galvatron with Clench and later as [[Megazarak]] with his Caliburn.
{{Clear}}
==Transformers: Timelines== {{Transformers character| name =Leader-1 |image = |caption = |japanname = |affiliation =Autobot |subgroup = |rank = |function = |partner = |motto = |alternatemodes =Jet |series =''[[Transformers: Timelines]]'' |engvoice = |japanvoice = }} Leader-1 is one of the Autobots under the command of the evil dictator Optimus Prime in the ''Shattered Glass'' story. He was on guard duty when he was taken down by Rampage. {{Clear}}

{{Infobox person | image = File:Li Quan with Tiger.jpg | caption = Director of China Tiger Revival, Li Quan | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Beijing]], [[China]] | birth_name = Li Quan | spouse = | children = | years_active = 1999–present | occupation = Conservationist | website = http://chinatigerrevival.org.uk/ }} '''Li Quan''' (全莉) is a Beijing-born tiger and wildlife [[conservation biology|conservationist]] who lives in [[London]]. She is credited with the concept of [[rewilding (conservation biology)|rewilding]] in the promotion of [[tiger]] conservation. This ensures zoo-born tigers develop hunting and other survival skills in a controlled natural environment prior to their return to the wild.<ref name="Liu2010">{{cite web |title=Rewilded: Saving the South China Tiger |url=http://www.dimsum.co.uk/features/rewilded-saving-the-south-china-tiger.html |accessdate=27 August 2011 |first=Cecily |last=Liu |date=16 October 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110929122435/http://www.dimsum.co.uk/features/rewilded-saving-the-south-china-tiger.html |archivedate=29 September 2011 |df= }}</ref><ref name="Blandy2007">{{cite web |title=South China tiger finds hope in South Africa |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/editorials/archives/2007/12/13/2003392378 |accessdate=27 August 2011 |first=Fran |last=Blandy |date=13 December 2007}}</ref>
She initiated the world’s first such experiment by rewilding [[South China tiger]]s in collaboration with the [[State Forestry Administration of China]] at the [[Laohu Valley Reserve]] in [[South Africa]]. The concept was initially controversial, but it is now widely accepted as a viable strategy for wildlife conservation by many mainstream wildlife organizations including the [[World Wide Fund for Nature]].
Quan has founded several charities related to tiger and wildlife conservation. She is now a director of China Tiger Revival.<ref name="Wild10.org">{{cite web|title=Unsung Heroes - Li Quan|url=http://wild10.org/blog/unsung-heroes-li-quan |accessdate=29 August 2015|first=Wild|last=10|date=5 February 2015}}</ref> Prior to devoting herself to wildlife conservation she was global head of licensing at the fashion house [[Gucci]]. She is a graduate of [[Beijing University]], and holds a dual MBA/MA degree from the [[Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania|Wharton Business School]] and the [[Lauder Institute]] at the [[University of Pennsylvania]].<ref name="CriEnglish2008">{{cite web |title=Quan Li, Riding on the Tiger, Never Want to Get Off |url=http://english.cri.cn/4406/2008/05/09/1141@355412.htm |accessdate=28 August 2015 |first=Cri |last=English|date=5 August 2009}}</ref>
She is the author of two books, ''Rewilded, Saving the South China Tiger'' (bilingual, English and Chinese), and ''Diary of the South China Tiger'' (Chinese).<ref name="Evans Mitchell Book">{{cite web |title=https://www.embooks.co.uk/li-quan |first=British|last=Pound|date=5 August 2014}}</ref> She also authored the South China Tiger Rewilding Guidelines for the Wildlife R&D Centre of the State Forestry Administration of China: http://tigerliquan.blogspot.com/2012/07/south-china-tiger-rewilding-guidelines.html ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}}

revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:List of organisms named after the ''Harry Potter'' series}} {{EngvarB|date=May 2018}} [[Image:The Childrens Museum of Indianapolis - Dracorex skeletal reconstruction.jpg|thumb|The skeleton of ''Dracorex hogwartsia'', a species whose name translates as "The Dragon-King of Hogwarts."]] Newly created taxonomic names in [[biological nomenclature]] often reflect the discoverer's interests or honour those the discoverer holds in esteem. This is a list of real organisms with scientific names chosen to reference the fictional ''[[Harry Potter]]'' series by [[J.K. Rowling]].
== Vertebrates ==
* ''[[Clevosaurus sectumsemper]]'' is an extinct [[Clevosaurus|Gloucester lizard]]. It is named after the [[Magic in Harry Potter|sectumsempra curse]].<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-bristol-33009107 | title = Harry Potter sectumsempra spell inspires lizard name | publisher = BBC | date = 4 Jun 2015 | accessdate = 14 Jan 2018 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20161203105652/http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-bristol-33009107 | archivedate = 3 Dec 2016 |dead-url=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Klein |first1=Catherine G. |last2=Whiteside |first2=David I. |last3=de Lucas |first3=Victor Selles |last4=Viegas |first4=Pedro A. |last5=Benton |first5=Michael J. |title=A distinctive Late Triassic microvertebrate fissure fauna and a new species of ''Clevosaurus'' (Lepidosauria: Rhynchocephalia) from Woodleaze Quarry, Gloucestershire, UK |journal=Proceedings of the Geologists' Association |date=2015 |volume=126 |issue=3 |pages=402–416 |doi=10.1016/j.pgeola.2015.05.003}}</ref>
* ''[[Dracorex hogwartsia]]'' is an extinct species of [[dinosaur]] in the family [[Pachycephalosauria]]. It is named after [[Hogwarts]], the school which provides much of the setting for the ''Harry Potter'' series.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.nhm.ac.uk/discover/dino-directory/dracorex.html | title = Dracorex | publisher = Natural History Museum | accessdate = 14 Jan 2018 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170929125545/http://www.nhm.ac.uk/discover/dino-directory/dracorex.html | archivedate = 29 Sep 2017}}</ref>
== Invertebrates ==
* ''[[Ampulex dementor]]'' is a species of [[Ampulicidae|cockroach wasp]]. It is named after the [[dementors]], guards of Azkaban prison which suck to souls of those they encounter.<ref name="plosone">{{cite journal|last=Ohl|first=Michael|author2=Lohrmann, Volker |author3=Breitkreuz, Laura |author4=Kirschey, Lukas |author5= Krause, Stefanie |title=The Soul-Sucking Wasp by Popular Acclaim – Museum Visitor Participation in Biodiversity Discovery and Taxonomy|journal=PLoS ONE|date=2014|volume=9|issue=4|pages=e95068|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0095068|url=http://www.plosone.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0095068 |pmid=24755672 |pmc=3995701}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/speaking-of-science/wp/2015/05/27/say-hello-to-the-dementor-wasp-it-turns-cockroaches-into-zombies/ | first = Elahe | last = Izadi | title = Say hello to the dementor wasp. It turns cockroaches into zombies. | accessdate =14 Jan 2018 | date = 27 May 2015}}</ref>
* ''[[Aname aragog]]'' is a species of spider in the family [[Nemesiidae]], named after Aragog, a fictional spider owned by [[Rubeus Hagrid]].<ref name="wamus">{{cite web|url=http://museum.wa.gov.au/online-collections/names/aname-aragog|title = Aname aragog | accessdate = 15 Jan 2018 | publisher = Western Australian Museum Online Collections | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20180115155924/http://museum.wa.gov.au/online-collections/names/aname-aragog| archivedate = 15 Jan 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Harvey | first1= Frances S. B. | last2 = Framenau | first2 = Volker W. | last3 = Wojcieszek | first3 = Janine M. |last4 = Rix | first4 = Michael G. | last5= Harvey | first5 = Mark S. | date = 2012 | title = Molecular and morphological characterisation of new species in the trapdoor spider genus ''Aname'' (Araneae: Mygalomorphae: Nemesiidae) from the Pilbara bioregion of Western Australia | journal = Zootaxa | volume = 3383 | pages = 15-38 | url = http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/f/zt03383p038.pdf | accessdate = 15 Jan 2018 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170117190740/http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/f/zt03383p038.pdf | archivedate = 17 Jan 2017}}</ref>
* ''[[Eriovixia gryffindori]]'' is a species of [[Orb-weaver spider]] named after the Hogwarts house [[Gryffindor]]; the spider resembles the [[Magical_objects_in_Harry_Potter#Sorting_Hat|sorting hat]] which separates new Hogwarts students into their houses.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.livescience.com/57181-harry-potter-sorting-hat-spider.html | title = Hat-Shaped Spider Named for Magical Object in 'Harry Potter' | first = Mindy | last = Weisberger | accessdate = 14 Jan 2018 | date = 13 Dec 2016 | publisher = Live Science | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170606060028/https://www.livescience.com/57181-harry-potter-sorting-hat-spider.html | archivedate = 6 Jun 2017}}</ref>
* ''[[Graphorn]]'' is a genus of [[Pentatomidae|stink bug]] named after the graphorn, a dangerous magical creature from ''[[Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them]]''.<ref name="Faundez et al., 2017">{{cite journal|last1=Faúndez|first1=Eduardo I.|last2=Rider|first2=David A.|last3=Carvajal|first3=Mariom A.|title=''Graphorn bicornutus'', a new genus and a new species from Argentina (Heteroptera: Pentatomidae)|journal=Arquivos Entomolóxicos|date=2017|volume=17|pages=285-288|url=http://www.aegaweb.com/arquivos_entomoloxicos/ae17_2017_faundez_et_al_graphorn_bicornutus_new%20genus_new_species_argentina_heteroptera_pentatomidae.pdf|archive-url=http://www.aegaweb.com/arquivos_entomoloxicos/ae17_2017_faundez_et_al_graphorn_bicornutus_new%20genus_new_species_argentina_heteroptera_pentatomidae.pdf|dead-url=no|archive-date=15 March 2018}}</ref>
* ''[[Harryplax severus]]'' is a species of [[Pseudozioidea|pseudozioid crab]]. According to the publication first describing both the genus and species,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Mendoza|first1=Jose C.E.|last2=Ng|first2=Peter K.L.|title=''Harryplax severus'', a new genus and species of an unusual coral rubble-inhabiting crab from Guam (Crustacea, Brachyura, Christmaplacidae)|journal=ZooKeys|date=2017|volume=647|pages=23–35|doi=10.3897/zookeys.647.11455}}</ref> the genus name ''Harryplax'' was chosen both to honor [[Harry T. Conley]] and as an allusion to [[Harry Potter (character)|Harry Potter]]. The genus is monotypic, with ''H. severus'' as its only member species. The species name refers to [[Severus Snape]], a teacher and headmaster of Hogwarts.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Greshko|first1=Michael|title=Pale, Beady-Eyed Crab Named for Harry Potter|url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/2017/01/new-crab-species-harry-potter-characters-severus/|website=National Geographic News|date=23 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Geggel|first1=Laura|title=Accio Crab! Newfound Crab Honors Harry Potter and Professor Snape|url=http://www.livescience.com/57601-newfound-crab-named-for-harry-potter.html|website=Live Science|date=23 January 2017}}</ref>
* ''[[Lusius malfoyi]]'' is a species of parasitoid wasp found in [[New Zealand]]. The species name was chosen to reference [[Lucius Malfoy]], the parent of one of Harry's classmates at Hogwarts.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/10/10/new-zealand-wasp-named-harry-potter-character-lucius-malfoy/ | title = New Zealand wasp named after Harry Potter character Lucius Malfoy | first = Jonathan | last = Pearlman | publisher = The Telegraph | date = 10 Oct 2017 | accessdate = 14 Jan 2018 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20180114025328/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/10/10/new-zealand-wasp-named-harry-potter-character-lucius-malfoy/ | archivedate = 14 Jan 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/oct/10/lusius-malfoyi-wasp-new-zealand-insect-named-after-harry-potter-villain | title = Lusius malfoyi wasp: New Zealand insect named after Harry Potter villain | first = Elanor | last = Ainge Roy | publisher = The Guardian | accessdate = 14 Jan 2018 | date = 10 Oct 2017 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20171119112845/https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/oct/10/lusius-malfoyi-wasp-new-zealand-insect-named-after-harry-potter-villain | archivedate = 19 Oct 2017}}</ref> The genus ''[[Lusius]]'' was first described in 1903 and is not a ''Harry Potter'' reference.<ref>{{cite journal | first1 = Thomas E. | last1 = Saunders | first2 = Darren F. | last2 = Ward | title = A new species of Lusius (Hymenoptera: Ichneumonidae) from New Zealand | journal = New Zealand Entomologist | date = 2017 | volume = 40 | issue = 2 | pages = 72-78 | doi = 10.1080/00779962.2017.1357427}}</ref>
* ''[[Lycosa aragogi]]'' is a species of [[wolf spider]] named after the spider Aragog, owned by [[Rubeus Hagrid]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/books/a-new-spider-species-has-been-named-after-a-harry-potter-character/story-U4ykWNluEApj8ivK4fqKEO.html|title=A new spider species has been named after a Harry Potter character|date=9 July 2017|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.livescience.com/59729-wolf-spider-honors-harry-potter-aragog.html | title = Furry 'Harry Potter' Spider Discovered in Mountain Burrow | date = 7 Jul 2017 | first = Laura | last = Geggel | accessdate = 14 Jan 2018 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20180103213416/https://www.livescience.com/59729-wolf-spider-honors-harry-potter-aragog.html | archivedate = 3 Jan 2018}}</ref>
* ''[[Ochyrocera aragogue]]'' is a species of spider in the family [[Ochyroceratidae]]. It is also named after Hagrid's pet Aragog.<ref name="Brescovit">{{cite web|last1=Brescovit|first1=Antonio|title=Seven new species of the spider genus Ochyrocera from caves in Floresta Nacional de Carajás, PA, Brazil|url=https://zookeys.pensoft.net/article/19778/list/6/|website=ZooKeys|accessdate=12 January 2018}}</ref>
* ''[[Thestral (bug)|Thestral]]'' is genus of stink bug named after [[Magical_creatures_in_Harry_Potter#Thestrals|thestrals]], elusive and magical winged horses which pull carriages carrying students from [[Places_in_Harry_Potter#Hogsmeade|Hogsmeade]] train station.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://phys.org/news/2014-11-insect-harry-potter-creature.html | title = Researchers name new insect for 'Harry Potter' creature | publisher = Phys.org | date = 20 Nov 2014 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160320171154/http://phys.org/news/2014-11-insect-harry-potter-creature.html | archivedate = 20 Mar 2016 | accessdate = 14 Jan 2018}}</ref>
== See also ==

{{For|parasitoids|Parasitoid}} This is an ''incomplete list'' of [[organisms]] that are true '''[[parasitism|parasites]]''' upon other organisms.
==Endoparasites== (''endo'' = within; parasites that live inside their hosts)
===Plants=== * [[Rafflesia]] * [[Cuscuta]]
===[[Parasitic worm]]s=== These can be categorized into three groups; [[cestode]]s, [[nematode]]s and [[trematode]]s. Examples include: * [[Acanthocephala]] * [[Ascariasis]] (roundworms) * [[Cestoda]] (tapeworms) including: ''[[Taenia saginata]]'' (human beef tapeworm), ''[[Taenia solium]]'' (human pork tapeworm), ''[[Diphyllobothrium latum]]'' (fish tapeworm) and [[Echinococcosis]] (hydatid tapeworm) * ''[[Clonorchis sinensis]]'' (the Chinese liver fluke) * ''[[Dracunculus (nematode)|Dracunculus]] medinensis'' (Guinea worm) * ''[[Enterobius vermicularis]]'' (pinworm) * [[Filariasis]] * [[Hookworm]] * [[Loa loa]] * [[Onchocerciasis]] (river blindness) * [[Schistosomiasis]] * ''[[Strongyloides stercoralis]]'' * [[Tapeworm]] * ''[[Toxocara canis]]'' (dog roundworm) * [[Trichinella]] * [[Whipworm]]
===[[Protozoans]]=== * ''[[Entamoeba histolytica]]'' and ''[[Entamoeba coli]]'' - can cause [[Amoebiasis]] * ''[[Acanthamoeba]]'' * ''[[Balamuthia mandrillaris]]'' * ''[[Giardia]]'' * ''[[Cyclospora cayetanensis]]'' * ''[[Cryptosporidium]]'' * ''[[Toxoplasma gondii]]'' * ''[[Leishmania]]'' - ''[[Leishmania tropica|L. tropica]]'', ''[[Leishmania donovani|L. donovani]]'', and ''[[Leishmania mexicana|L. mexicana]]'' are known to cause [[Leishmaniasis]]. * ''[[Plasmodium]]'' - causes the fatal disease, [[Malaria]]. ''[[Plasmodium falciparum|P. falciparum]]'', ''[[Plasmodium vivax|P. vivax]]'', and ''[[Plasmodium malariae|P. malariae]]'' are pathogenic to humans. * ''[[Babesia]]''
===Fungi=== * ''[[Gymnosporangium]]'' and other [[Rust (fungus)|rust]]s * ''[[Pyrenophora teres]]'' * ''[[Cordyceps]]''
==Ectoparasites== (''ecto'' = outside; parasites that live on but not within their hosts, for example, attached to their skin)
===Arthropoda=== * [[Acari]] **''[[Varroa destructor]]'' * ''[[Cymothoa exigua]]'' * [[Bed bug (insect)|Bed bugs]] * [[Culicidae]] (mosquitoes) * [[Calyptra]] (vampire moths) * [[Hippoboscoidea]] ** [[Tsetse fly]] ** ''[[Lipoptena]]'' ** ''[[Melophagus ovinus]]'', (sheep keds) and relatives * [[Oestridae]] (bot flies) ** [[Human botfly]] * [[Phlebotominae]] (sand flies) * [[Phthiraptera]] (Lice) ** [[Body louse]] ** [[Crab louse]] ** [[Head louse]] * [[Siphonaptera]] (fleas) * [[Tabanidae]] (horse flies) * [[Tantulocarida]] * [[Triatominae]] * [[Pea crab]] * ''[[Sacculina]]''
===Annelids=== * [[Hirudinea]] (some [[leech]]es)
===Monogeneans===
[[Monogenea]]ns are [[flatworm]]s, generally ectoparasites on [[fish]]. * ''[[Calydiscoides euzeti]]'' * ''[[Lethacotyle vera]]'' * ''[[Protocotyle euzetmaillardi]]'' * ''[[Pseudorhabdosynochus]]'' spp.
===Mollusks=== * [[Cancellaria cooperii]] * [[Glochidium]] * [[Pyramidellidae]]
=== Chordates === * [[Cookiecutter shark]] * [[Candiru]] (vampire fish of Brazil, a facultative parasite) * [[Lamprey]]s * Male [[Deep sea angler]]s * [[False cleanerfish]] * [[Hood mockingbird]] * [[Oxpecker]]s ([[cleaning symbiosis]]) * [[Snubnosed eel]] * [[Vampire bat]] * [[Vampire finch]] * [[Cuckoo]] ([[brood parasite]]) * [[Cowbird]] (brood parasite)
===Plants=== * [[Mistletoe]] * Certain [[orchid]]s
===Fungi=== * [[Corn smut]] * Certain [[mushroom]]s

{{For|the Holy Roman Empress|Maria Leopoldine of Austria}} {{Infobox royalty | name = Maria Leopoldina of Austria | image = Maria Leopoldina 1815.jpg | caption = Leopoldina at age 18, 1815 | consort = yes | succession = [[List of Brazilian consorts|Empress consort of Brazil]] | reign = {{nowrap|12 October 1822 – 11 December 1826}} | succession1 = [[List of Portuguese consorts|Queen consort of Portugal]] | reign1 = 10 March 1826 – 2 May 1826 | birth_date = 22 January 1797 | birth_place = [[Schönbrunn Palace]], [[Vienna]], [[Archduchy of Austria|Austria]], [[Holy Roman Empire]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1826|12|11|1797|1|22|df=y}} | death_place = [[Paço de São Cristóvão|São Cristóvão Palace]], [[Rio de Janeiro]], [[Empire of Brazil]] | burial_date = 1954 | burial_place = [[Monument to the Independence of Brazil]], [[São Paulo]] | spouse = {{marriage|[[Pedro I of Brazil and IV of Portugal]]|1817}} | full name = {{lang-de|Caroline Josepha Leopoldine Franziska Ferdinanda}} | issue = {{plainlist | * [[Maria II of Portugal|Maria II, Queen of Portugal]] * [[Miguel, Prince of Beira]] * [[João Carlos, Prince of Beira]] * [[Princess Januária of Brazil|Princess Januária, Countess of Aquila]] * [[Princess Paula of Brazil|Princess Paula]] * [[Princess Francisca of Brazil|Francisca, Princess of Joinville]] * [[Pedro II of Brazil|Pedro II, Emperor of Brazil]]}} | issue-link = #Children | issue-pipe = | house = [[House of Habsburg-Lorraine|Habsburg-Lorraine]] | father = [[Francis II, Holy Roman Emperor]] | mother = [[Maria Teresa of Naples and Sicily]] | religion = [[Roman Catholicism]] }} [[Don (honorific)|Dona]] '''Maria Leopoldina of Austria''' (22 January 1797 – 11 December 1826) was an [[archduchess]] of [[Austria]], [[Empress consort]] of [[Empire of Brazil|Brazil]] and [[Queen consort]] of [[Kingdom of Portugal|Portugal]].
She was born ''Caroline Josepha Leopoldine Franziska Ferdinanda of Habsburg-Lorraine'' in [[Vienna]], [[Austria]], the daughter of [[Holy Roman Emperor]] [[Francis II, Holy Roman Emperor|Francis II]], and his second wife, [[Maria Teresa of Naples and Sicily]]. Among her many siblings were Emperor [[Ferdinand I of Austria]] and [[Marie Louise, Duchess of Parma]], the wife of [[Napoleon I of France|Napoleon Bonaparte]].
== Early life == [[File:Maria Leopoline of Austria Brasilia2.jpg|thumb|left|Leopoldina in her youth, 1800s]] Leopoldina was born on 22 January 1797 in [[Schönbrunn Palace]], in [[Vienna]], [[Archduchy of Austria]]. She was given the name Caroline Josepha Leopoldine Franziska Ferdinanda,{{sfn|Oberacker|1988|p=31}} according to her biographer Carlos H. Oberacker, and confirmed by Bettina Kann in her work "Cartas de uma Imperatriz", who mentioned a contemporary source: the Austrian newspaper ''[[Wiener Zeitung]]'' of 25 January 1797, who gave the news of the birth of the Archduchess three days before with her full name. According to Oberacker, the name "Maria" wasn't present in the preserved baptismal record of the Archduchess,{{sfn|Oberacker|1988|pp=301–302}} and she began to use it only during her journey to Brazil, where she began to be named Maria Leopoldina in all documents, including the Constitutional oath of 1822. According to another theory presented by Oberacker, the Archduchess probably began to use the name "Maria" due to her great devotion to the [[Virgin Mary]] and because all her sisters-in-law used this name.
She was raised in accordance with the educational principles laid down by her grandfather, [[Emperor Leopold II]]. Among these was the habit of exercising her handwriting by writing the following text:<ref name="sunday">{{cite web | url=http://english.habsburger.net/module-en/das-sonntagskind-leopoldine | title=Leopoldine: Sunday's child | publisher=habsburger.net | work=The World of the Habsburgs | year=2010 | accessdate=March 9, 2012 | author=Schloß Schönbrunn | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130221174903/http://english.habsburger.net/module-en/das-sonntagskind-leopoldine | archivedate=February 21, 2013 | df= }}</ref> {{cquote|Do not oppress the poor. Be charitable. Do not complain about what God has given you, but improve your habits. We must strive earnestly to be good.}}
In addition, she and her sisters were taught to speak [[French language|French]] and [[Latin]]. They were also educated in drawing, piano, riding and hunting.<ref name="sunday" /> Her mother died when she was ten years old and her father went on to remarry [[Maria Ludovika of Austria-Este]]. Her late mother was a soprano and Leopoldina had the chance of meeting [[Johann Wolfgang von Goethe]] in 1810 and 1812, when she went to [[Karlovy Vary|Carlsbad]] with her stepmother.<ref name="sunday" /> Her passions included natural sciences, especially botany and mineralogy.<ref name="sunday" /> She was formed according to the three [[House of Habsburg|Habsburg]] principles: discipline, piety and a sense of duty.<ref name="sunday" />
Although Maria Theresa of Naples and Sicily was her birth mother, Leopoldina always considered Maria Ludovika d'Este, her stepmother, to be her mother and she grew up with Ludovika as her "spiritual mother".<ref name="sunday" />
== Marriage to Pedro== [[Image:Giovanni Passi 001.jpg|thumb|left|A coloured engraving representing ''Austria'' and ''Augusta'', the two ships that took Leopoldina to [[Brazil]], departing from [[Trieste]]]] On 24 September 1816 it was announced by Leopoldina's father that [[Pedro I of Brazil|Pedro of Braganza]] wished to take a Habsburg princess as his wife.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://english.habsburger.net/module-en/leopoldines-schicksalsjahr-1816 | title=1816 – A fateful year for Leopoldine | publisher=habsburger.net | work=The World of the Habsburgs | year=2010 | accessdate=March 9, 2012 | author=Schloß Schönbrunn | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120709144722/http://english.habsburger.net/module-en/leopoldines-schicksalsjahr-1816 | archivedate=July 9, 2012 | df= }}</ref> [[Klemens von Metternich]] suggested that it should be Leopoldina to go get married, as it was "her turn" to become a wife.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://english.habsburger.net/module-en/eine-anfrage-aus-rio-de-janeiro | title=An enquiry from Rio de Janeiro | publisher=habsburger.net | work=The World of Habsburgs | year=2010 | accessdate=March 9, 2012 | author=Schloß Schönbrunn | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120715095244/http://english.habsburger.net/module-en/eine-anfrage-aus-rio-de-janeiro | archivedate=July 15, 2012 | df= }}</ref> Two ships were prepared and in April 1817 scientists, painters, gardeners and a taxidermist, all with assistants, travelled to [[Rio de Janeiro]] ahead of Leopoldina, whom, in the meantime, studied the history and geography of her future home and learned [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]]. During these weeks Leopoldina compiled and wrote a [[vade mecum]], a unique document the like of which has never been produced by any other Habsburg princess.<ref name="tropics">{{cite web | url=http://english.habsburger.net/module-en/heirat-reise-nach-brasilien-expedition | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111207191259/http://english.habsburger.net/module-en/heirat-reise-nach-brasilien-expedition | dead-url=yes | archive-date=December 7, 2011 | title=An expedition to the tropics | publisher=habsburger.net | work=The World of the Habsburgs | year=2010 | accessdate=March 9, 2012 | author=Schloß Schönbrunn }}</ref>
On 13 May 1817 Leopoldina was married to Dom Pedro ''per procuram'' (by proxy) in Vienna. At the ceremony the bridegroom was represented by Leopoldina’s uncle, [[Archduke Charles, Duke of Teschen|Archduke Charles]]. Embarkation took place in Livorno on 13 August 1817 among much celebration, and after an adventure-filled voyage lasting 81 days, Leopoldina arrived in Rio de Janeiro on 5 November and finally met her husband.<ref name="prince">{{cite web | url=http://english.habsburger.net/module-en/ein-portugiesischer-maerchenprinz | title=A Portuguese fairy-tale prince? | publisher=habsburger.net | work=The World of the Habsburgs | year=2010 | accessdate=March 9, 2012 | author=Schloß Schönbrunn | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111206173723/http://english.habsburger.net/module-en/ein-portugiesischer-maerchenprinz | archivedate=December 6, 2011 | df= }}</ref> [[File:Debret-desembarque.jpg|thumb|right|Arrival of Archduchess Leopoldina in [[Rio de Janeiro]], 5 November 1817.]] From a distance Pedro initially appeared to Leopoldina to be a perfect, well-educated gentleman, but the reality was very different. Dom Pedro was a year younger than Leopoldina and sadly rarely measured up to the descriptions given by the matchmakers. His temperament was impulsive and choleric, and his education but modest. Even spoken communication between the young married couple proved difficult, as Pedro spoke very little French and his Portuguese could only be described as vulgar.<ref name="prince" />
In keeping with Portuguese tradition, at the age of eighteen Pedro of Braganza not only had a string of amorous adventures behind him and was principally interested in horse racing and love affairs, but in 1817 (the year of his marriage to Leopoldina) he was living as if in wedlock with French dancer Noemie Thierry, who was finally removed from the court by his father a month after Leopoldina's arrival in Rio de Janeiro.<ref name="prince" />
The young married couple took up residence in six relatively small rooms in the [[Paço de São Cristóvão|Palace of São Cristóvão]]. The inner courtyard and path to the stables were unpaved and the tropical rainfall quickly turned everything to mud. There were insects everywhere, including in their clothing, for the uniforms and court regalia made of velvet and plush rotted and turned mouldy in the heat and humidity.<ref name="prince" />
==Regent of Brazil==
[[File:D. Leopoldina - ca. 1817.jpg|thumb|left|Leopoldina wearing court dress and the insignia of the [[Order of the Southern Cross|Imperial Order of the Southern Cross]], c. 1817]] On 25 April 1821, the court returned to Portugal. A fleet of 11 ships took the king, the court, the royal house and the royal treasury, and only Prince Pedro remained in Brazil as regent of the country, with ample powers counterbalanced by a regency council. At first Pedro was incapable of dominating the chaos: the situation was dominated by the Portuguese troops, in anarchic conditions. The opposition between Portuguese and Brazilians became increasingly evident. It is clear from Leopoldina's correspondence that she has warmly espoused the cause of the Brazilian people and even desired the independence of the country and is therefore loved and venerated by the Brazilians.
According to Ezekiel Ramirez, below, the signs of a nascent Brazilian unit as an independent nation in the southern provinces were visible, but the north supported the Lisbon Cortes and called for regional independence. If the Prince Regent had left the country at that moment, Brazil would be lost to Portugal because the courts of Lisbon repeated the same error that led the Spanish courts to lose the colonies, seeking to establish direct contacts with each province in particular.
In Rio, thousands of signatures collected required the regents to remain in Brazil. "José Bonifácio de Andrada e Silva's courageous attitude toward Portuguese arrogance greatly encouraged the aspirations for unity that existed in the southern provinces, especially in São Paulo. A highly educated men led this movement." After Fico's day, 9 January 1822, a new ministry was organized under the leadership of Jose Bonifacio, "strictly monarchist", and the Prince Royal soon won the trust of the people. On 15 February 1822 the Portuguese troops left Rio, and their departure represented the dissolution of the ties between Brazil and the metropolis. The prince was triumphantly received in Minas Gerais.
When her husband, prince regent, traveled to São Paulo in August 1822 to pacify politics (which culminated in the proclamation of Brazil's independence in September), Leopoldina exercised the regency. Great was his influence in the process of independence. The Brazilians were already aware that Portugal intended to call Pedro back, relegating Brazil again to the status of a simple colony rather than a [[Kingdom of Brazil|kingdom]] united to that of Portugal. There were fears that a civil war would separate the [[Province of São Paulo]] from the rest of Brazil. Pedro gave power to Leopoldina on 13 August 1822, appointing her head of the Council of State and Acting Princess Regent of the Kingdom of Brazil, with legal powers to govern the country during his absence and set out to appease São Paulo.
[[File:Maria Leopoldina regent.jpg|thumb|[[Dom (title)|Dona]] Leopoldina, then Princess Royal Regent of the [[Kingdom of Brazil]], presides a meeting of the Council of Ministers on September 2, 1822.]] The Princess received news that Portugal was preparing action against Brazil and, without time to wait for Pedro's return, Leopoldina, advised by Jose Bonifacio de Andrada e Silva, and using his attributes as interim head of government, met in the morning of 2 September 1822, with the Council of State, signing the decree of Independence, declaring Brazil separate from Portugal. The Princess sends Pedro a letter, along with another letter from José Bonifácio, as well as comments from Portugal criticizing the actions of her husband and King João VI. It demands that Pedro proclaim the Independence of Brazil and, in the letter, warns: "The pommel is ripe, pick it up already, or it will rot."
The officer arrived at the prince on 7 September 1822. Leopoldina had also sent papers received from [[Lisbon]], and comments from Antônio Carlos Ribeiro de Andrada, deputy to the courts, for which the Prince-Regent learned of criticism of him in the metropolis. The position of John VI and all his ministry, dominated by the courts, was difficult.
While awaiting the return of Pedro, Leopoldina, the interim ruler of an already independent Brazil, idealized the flag of Brazil, in which she mixed the green of the [[House of Braganza]] and the golden yellow of the [[House of Lorraine|House of Habsburg]]. Other authors say that [[Jean-Baptiste Debret]], the French artist who designed what he saw in Brazil in the 1820s, was the author of the national pavilion that replaced that of the old Portuguese court, symbol of the oppression of the old regime. Debret is the design of the beautiful imperial flag, in collaboration with Jose Bonifacio de Andrada e Silva, in which the green rectangle of the Braganza represented the forests and the yellow rhombus, color of the Habsburg-Lorraine dynasty, represented the gold.
== Empress of Brazil ==
[[File:Leopoldina-schlapritz-mcm.jpg|thumb|left|Leopoldina, Empress consort of Brazil]] [[File:Juramento da Imperatriz Leopoldina à Constituição do Império 02.tiff|thumb|Oath of the Empress Maria Leopoldina to the Brazilian Constitution, 1824.]] Maria Leopoldina became Brazil's first [[Queen consort|empress consort]]. She also played an important role in the process of issuing a [[Brazilian Declaration of Independence|Declaration of Independence]]. On 2 September 1822, a new decree with demands from Lisbon arrived in [[Rio de Janeiro]], while Prince Pedro was in [[São Paulo]]. Leopoldina, advised by [[José Bonifácio de Andrada e Silva|José Bonifácio]], and using her power as [[Prince Regent|Princess Regent]], met on 2 September 1822 with the Council of Ministers. She decided to send her husband the news along with a letter advising him to declare Brazil's independence and warned him, "The fruit is ready, it's time to harvest." Prince Pedro declared the country's independence upon receiving the letter on 7 September 1822.
When his father, [[João VI of Portugal|João VI]], died on 10 March 1826, Pedro inherited the Portuguese throne as King Pedro IV, while remaining Emperor Pedro I of Brazil. Maria Leopoldina thus became both Empress consort of Brazil and Queen consort of Portugal. However, two months later, Pedro was forced to give up the Portuguese throne to their seven-year-old daughter [[Maria II of Portugal|Maria]].
At the end of November 1826, Pedro traveled to Cisplatina (now Uruguay) to join his soldiers. To mark the occasion there was a large farewell reception on 20 November 1826, and Pedro demanded that both women, Maria Leopoldina and his official mistress [[Domitila de Castro, Marchioness of Santos]], appear together before the ecclesiastical and diplomatic dignitaries and receive his kiss on the hand. With the fulfillment of this demand, Maria Leopoldina would have officially recognized her husband's mistress, and for this she refused to appear at the reception. This caused a bitter argument with Pedro, who departed with no resolution to the situation.<ref name ="Kaiser">[http://cas.umn.edu/assets/pdf/dona_leopoldina.pdf Gloria Kaiser: ''Dona Leopoldina – Habsburg Princess, Empress of Brazil'', 2009, p. 15] [retrieved 14 July 2015].</ref>
Shortly after, Maria Leopoldina became ill, had spells of fever, became delirious at times, and then suffered a miscarriage on 2 December 1826. She died eight days later, on 11 December, five weeks before her thirtieth birthday. She was buried on 14 December 1826 in Rio de Janeiro, in the church of the Ajuda Convent.<ref name ="Kaiser"/>

Maria II's first husband, [[Auguste de Beauharnais, 2nd Duke of Leuchtenberg]], died a few months after the marriage. Her second husband was Prince Ferdinand of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha, who became King Dom [[Fernando II of Portugal|Fernando II]] after the birth of their first child. She had eleven children from this marriage. Maria II was heir to her brother Pedro II as [[Prince Imperial of Brazil|Princess Imperial]] until her exclusion from the Brazilian line of succession by law no. 91 of 30 October 1835.{{sfn|Barman|1999|p=438}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Miguel, Prince of Beira]] | | 26 April 1820 | [[Prince of Beira]] from birth to his death. |- ! scope="row" | [[João Carlos, Prince of Beira]] | | 6 March 1821 – <br /> 4 February 1822 | Prince of Beira from birth to his death. |- ! scope="row" | [[Princess Januária of Brazil]] | [[File:Januaria of Brazil 1865b.jpg|100px|alt=Sepia photograph showing the head and shoulders of a middle-aged woman wearing a dark dress with thin white collar]] | 11 March 1822 – <br /> 13 March 1901 | Married [[Prince Louis, Count of Aquila|Prince Luigi, Count of Aquila]], son of Don [[Francis I of the Two Sicilies|Francesco I]], [[Kingdom of the Two Sicilies|King of the Two Sicilies]]. She had four children from this marriage. Officially recognized as an [[Infante|Infanta]] of Portugal on 4 June 1822,{{sfn|Morato|1835|p=17}} she was later considered excluded from the Portuguese line of succession after Brazil became independent.{{sfn|Morato|1835|pp=33–34}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Princess Paula of Brazil]] | [[File:Dona_Paula_Mariana_Joana_Carlota_de_Bragança.jpg|100px]] | 17 February 1823 – <br /> 16 January 1833 | She died age 9, probably of [[meningitis]].{{sfn|Barman|1999|p=42}} Born in Brazil after its independence, Paula was excluded from the Portuguese line of succession.{{sfn|Morato|1835|pp=17–18}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Princess Francisca of Brazil]] | [[File:FranciscaGonzagaDeBranganca.jpg|100px|alt=Faded sepia photograph showing the head and shoulders of a lady wearing a veil over her hair]] | 2 August 1824 – <br /> 27 March 1898 | Married [[Prince François, Prince of Joinville]], son of [[Louis Philippe I|Louis Philippe I]], [[July Monarchy|King of the French]].
